title: Implement unique explosion animations per weapon
description:
Give each weapon type a visually distinct explosion effect.

## Explosion Designs

### Standard Shell
- Classic orange/red fireball (current design)
- Standard particle spread

### Heavy Artillery
- Larger initial flash
- Deep orange/brown colors
- More particles, slower dissipation
- Ground shake effect (screen shake)
- Debris particles

### Precision Shot
- Smaller, intense white/blue flash
- Quick, sharp explosion
- Fewer but faster particles
- Minimal smoke

### Cluster Bomb
- Initial pop, then 3-5 secondary explosions
- Secondary explosions smaller, spread around impact
- Staggered timing (50-150ms delays)
- Each sub-explosion has own particles

### Napalm
- Orange/red initial burst
- Lingering flame effect (longer duration)
- Fire particles that stick to ground briefly
- Smoke rises longer
- Warm color palette (no blue/white)

## Implementation
- Extend `renderExplosion()` in explosion.ts
- Add `weaponType` to ExplosionState
- Switch on type for different particle configs
- Cluster bomb needs special handling for sub-explosions

## Tests
- Each weapon type renders distinct explosion
- Timing appropriate for weapon theme
- Cluster bomb sub-explosions work correctly
- Napalm lingering effect visible
- No performance issues with particle counts

title: Campaign Mode Epic
description:
Multi-game campaign mode with persistent progression, AI economy, and leaderboard tracking.

## Overview
Campaign mode allows players to compete in a series of games (3, 5, 8, or 13 games) against AI tanks named after legendary historical generals. Features include:

- **Campaign Lengths**: 3, 5, 8, or 13 games
- **Named AI Tanks**: All foes are named after legendary generals of human history
- **Separate Economy**: Everyone starts with $500, money earned only counts within the campaign
- **Single Active Campaign**: Can resume incomplete campaign, but only 1 at a time
- **AI Economy**: Enemy tanks earn money and buy weapons like the player
- **Skill Progression**: All tanks start at selected difficulty, level up every 3 kills
- **Streamlined Config**: Battle configuration shown only at campaign start
- **Leaderboard**: After each game, shows all combatants' stats, money, level, and ranking

## UI Changes
- Loading screen START button splits into 'Free Play' or 'Campaign'
- New campaign prompts for campaign length selection
- Existing campaign prompts 'Resume Campaign' or 'New Campaign'
- New leaderboard screen after each campaign game

title: Campaign Game Flow Controller
description:
Implement the campaign game flow that skips config after first game and manages transitions.

## Requirements
- First game of campaign:
  - Show GameConfigScreen to select settings
  - Settings locked for entire campaign
  - Show WeaponShop before game

- Subsequent games (2+):
  - Skip GameConfigScreen entirely
  - Use locked campaign config
  - Show WeaponShop only (player can buy with campaign balance)
  - AI also 'shops' between games

## Campaign game flow
1. Game ends → record results to campaign state
2. Update participant stats (kills, deaths, balance, level)
3. Save campaign state to localStorage
4. Show CampaignLeaderboard
5. User clicks 'Continue'
6. If not final game:
   - AI shopping phase (background)
   - Show WeaponShop (uses campaign balance)
   - Start next game with same config
7. If final game:
   - Show final standings
   - Option to start new campaign or return to free play

## Game initialization for campaign
- Use locked config from campaign state
- Initialize tanks with their campaign inventories
- Set AI difficulty based on each tank's current level
- Carry over money but not health (everyone starts at 100% each game)

## Files to modify
- src/App.tsx (campaign flow logic)
- src/context/GameContext.tsx (campaign phase management)
- src/components/WeaponShop.tsx (use campaign balance in campaign mode)
- src/services/userDatabase.ts (campaign state updates)

title: Integrate weapon inventory with game loop
description:
Wire up the weapon inventory system with the main game loop.

## Integration Points

### Game Start (App.tsx)
- Load player's weapon inventory from UserContext
- Initialize in-game ammo counts from inventory
- Set default weapon selection (standard or first owned)

### Firing Phase
- Use currently selected weapon for projectile creation
- Decrement ammo count for non-standard weapons
- Update weapon panel to reflect new count
- If weapon depleted, auto-switch to standard

### Weapon Shop Phase
- Occurs between rounds (if multi-round) or at game start
- Purchases persist to UserContext inventory
- Can skip if player has sufficient weapons

### Game End
- Any unused special weapons remain in inventory (persistent)
- No refunds, but weapons carry over to next game

## State Flow
1. UserContext.inventory → GameState.weaponAmmo (copy on game start)
2. Player fires → GameState.weaponAmmo decremented
3. Game ends → remaining ammo NOT returned (used or lost)
4. Shop purchases → UserContext.inventory updated

## Tests
- Inventory loads correctly at game start
- Ammo decrements on fire
- Auto-switch when weapon depleted
- Purchases persist across games
- Standard weapon never depletes

title: Tank Destruction Animations by Weapon Type
description:
Implement visually distinct tank destruction animations based on the weapon type that deals the killing blow.

## Animation Types

### Explosive Destruction
- Triggered by: Baby Missile, Missile, Baby Nuke, Nuke, MIRV
- Tank explodes outward with debris flying in all directions
- Parts scatter with physics-based trajectories
- Smoke and fire effects

### Ballistic/Sniper Destruction  
- Triggered by: Shot, Super Shot, Sniper (if added)
- Tank falls apart/crumbles
- Parts detach and fall with gravity
- Less dramatic, more mechanical failure aesthetic

### Fire/Burn Destruction
- Triggered by: Napalm, Flamethrower (if added)
- Tank burns and melts
- Fire particles emanating from tank
- Gradual destruction with charring effect

## Technical Requirements
- Detect weapon type that killed the tank
- Pass weapon category to destruction animation system
- Each animation type should have distinct visual identity
- Reuse existing particle/debris systems where possible

## Success Criteria
- Explosion weapons cause dramatic explosive tank destruction
- Sniper/ballistic weapons cause tank to fall apart mechanically
- Fire weapons cause burning/melting destruction
- Animations are visually distinct and satisfying

- Standard Shell: 100% → 35% damage (free base weapon)
- Heavy Artillery: 100% → 60% damage, $200 → $250

- Free: Standard (base weapon)
- Budget ($175-225): Utility weapons (EMP, Bouncing Betty, Homing)
- Premium ($250-350): High damage/utility (Heavy, Napalm, Bunker Buster, Cluster)
- Elite ($400): One-shot precision weapons

title: AI Economy System
description:
Implement money earning and weapon purchasing for AI tanks in campaign mode.

## Requirements
- AI tanks earn money the same way players do:
  - KILL_REWARD per kill (100)
  - WIN_BONUS for winning (250)
  - LOSS_CONSOLATION for losing (50)
  - Apply difficulty multipliers

- AI weapon purchasing logic:
  - Between games, AI decides what weapons to buy
  - Decision factors:
    - Current balance
    - Weapon cost vs effectiveness
    - Randomness based on difficulty (lower difficulty = more random choices)
  - Higher difficulty AI make smarter purchases
  - Each AI has its own inventory persisted in campaign state

- When AI fires, it uses weapons from its inventory (like player)
- selectAIWeapon() should check inventory before selecting

## Files to modify
- src/engine/ai.ts (add purchase logic, update weapon selection)
- src/engine/weapons.ts (may need helper functions)
- src/services/userDatabase.ts (campaign participant balance updates)

- Decrement stun counter at end of turn

Files to modify:

- src/components/Tank.tsx (visual effect)

Campaign Leaderboard Screen
description:
Create a leaderboard screen shown after each campaign game.

## Requirements
- Displayed after each game ends in campaign mode (instead of going directly to next game)
- Shows all campaign participants sorted by ranking

## Leaderboard columns
1. Rank (#1, #2, etc.) - based on points or wins
2. Tank Name (player name or general name)
3. Wins / Games Played (e.g., '2/3')
4. Total Kills
5. Total Deaths
6. K/D Ratio
7. Current Level (difficulty name + insignia)
8. Balance ($X)

## Ranking algorithm
Primary: Most wins
Secondary: Highest K/D ratio
Tertiary: Most kills

## UI Elements
- Title: 'Campaign Standings - Game X of Y'
- Leaderboard table with all participants
- Highlight player row
- Highlight eliminated tanks (0 wins or persistent death)
- 'Continue' button to proceed to next game
- If final game: 'Campaign Complete!' with different styling

## Files to create/modify
- src/components/CampaignLeaderboard.tsx (new component)
- src/context/GameContext.tsx (add leaderboard phase)
- src/types/game.ts (add phase if needed)
